Chapter 2. Building a blog with Gatsby

Basic development environment installation

In the previous post, the concepts of JAM Stack and Static Site Generator (SSG) were introduced. In this post, let's install Gatsby, a representative SSG, to create a basic framework for building a personal blog.

Gatsby is based on Nodejs/ReactJS. Therefore, the Node environment must be configured first. The basic configuration of the environment is as follows, so if the development environment is already configured, you can skip the contents below.

  1. Install NodeJS
  2. Git installation
  3. Install Gatsby

Install NodeJS and Git according to each environment. Then, the Gatsby installation environment is the same as the NPM environment.

For reference, my environment is Mac OS, so your Window/Linux environment may be slightly different.

Mac OS environment

  • Install NodeJS
brew install node
  • Git installation
brew install git

Windows environment

Then, download the installation file from Nodejs.org and install it.

  • Chapter: https://nodejs.org/en/download/
  • Install Git: https://github.com/git-for-windows/git/releases/tag/v2.31.1.windows.1

Linux environment

  • Install NodeJS
sudo apt-get install curl
curl -o- https://raw.githubusercontent.com/nvm-sh/nvm/v0.35.1/install.sh | bash
  • Git installation
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install git

Other integrated development environment (IDE) and Editor installation

I'm using Visual Studio Code (VS Code). However, you can freely install and use Atom, Eclipse, IntelliJ, etc. There are no special restrictions.

Visual Studio Code Download : https://code.visualstudio.com/download

Gatsby installation (environmental common)

  1. Install Gatsby CLI
npm install -g gatsby-cli

Now the development environment configuration is ready. Now, let's go to the actual project folder and create a basic project. Execute the following in the folder where the project is to be created.

  1. Create Gatsby Project

The types of Gatsby Project creation are as follows.

gatsby new [SITE_DIRECTORY_NAME] [URL_OF_STARTER_GITHUB_REPO]

If myblogyou start a new project named , you can create it by entering the following.

gatsby new myblog https://github.com/gatsbyjs/gatsby-starter-hello-world

If you do not enter the Github Repository that is the template prototype, the following is implicitly recognized as the prototype. https://github.com/gatsbyjs/gatsby-starter-default.git

  1. Running Gatsby development server
cd myblog
gatsby develop

Now that you've created a basic website with Gatsby, go into your project folder and look at the files. The following basic configuration files and folders will be created.

Depending on the template, more diverse components may be included.

developLet's run the environment for a trial run.

  1. Check access to Gatby development website

gatsby develop, you can connect to two services.

  • Website: http://localhost:8000/
  • GraphQL test: http://localhost:8000/___graphql
Website execution result GraphQL testing

You have now completed the basic Gatsby site configuration.

Gatsby Theme

We've just run Gatsby Hello World. In order to build a site using Gatsby, it is necessary to learn step by step over time how to configure Gatsby's framework based on ReactJS.

However, let's not forget that our purpose was to write a personal blog. We may lose our purpose and continue to delay building our blog while learning Gatsby. First of all, it would be better to build it simply and then update it one by one.

In this regard, Gatsby offers a variety of themes. There are various plug-ins in Gatsby, and the use of these plug-ins, file structure, and design are bundled together and provided as a theme. There are many official themes and unofficial themes shared by developers, but in this post, I will apply the Gatsby Official Blog theme (The Gatsby Blog theme).

Install The Gatsby Blog theme

Productivity with Gatsby is increasing thanks to a variety of themes. Without themes, Gatsby probably wouldn't have been this useful.

A blog theme changes a document written in markdown ( md파일or mdx파일) into a designed web page. Accordingly, the user can use his/her own personal blog by creating/adding a markdown file at a predetermined location. In addition, it is possible to change the design and function with only a few modifications.

In order to use the markdown file in the basic environment, you need gatsby-transformer-remarkto install/develop plug-ins such as etc. However, the theme provides a well-structured structure including this process.

1-1. When you start by creating a new project

gatsby new my-themed-blog https://github.com/gatsbyjs/gatsby-starter-blog-theme

1-2. When adding to an existing project

npm install gatsby-theme-blog

In the gatsby-config.js file, add the plugin as follows.

// gatsby-config.js
module.exports = {
  plugins: [
    {
      resolve: `gatsby-theme-blog`,
      options: {
        // basePath defaults to `/`
        basePath: `/blog`,
      },
    },
  ],
}

2. Blog Posting

  • Posting content: A /content/postsnew blog post is possible by creating a new markdown inside and writing the text according to the format.
  • Posting image: Images used in posting content /content/assetscan be placed in and used.
  • Markdown for posting follows the following format: ( ---Bullets surrounded by s frontmatterare called , and all posts must include a frontmatter. )
---
title: Hello World (example)
date: 2019-04-15
image: ./some-image.jpg
---

Posts should be written from here

One post is created for each markdown file. In other words, once the setting is completed, mdyou only need to manage the file for subsequent blog posts .

3. Website Settings

In addition to writing articles, since our blog is one of the websites, additional information such as the site name, description, and URL needs to be entered. Gatsby Blog Theme provides a field to gatsby-config.jsbatch process these settings in siteMetadat. Let's enter the website meta information. It will also be used for search engine optimization (SEO) in the future.

More specifically, a Gatsby-config.jsfile is imported from another component and used as a variable.

// gatsby-config.js
module.exports = {
  siteMetadata: {
    // Used for the site title and SEO
    title: `My Blog Title`,
    // Used to provide alt text for your avatar
    author: `My Name`,
    // Used for SEO
    description: `My site description...`,
    // Used for resolving images in social cards
    siteUrl: `https://example.com`,
    // Used for social links in the root footer
    social: [
      {
        name: `Twitter`,
        url: `https://twitter.com/gatsbyjs`,
      },
      {
        name: `GitHub`,
        url: `https://github.com/gatsbyjs`,
      },
    ],
  },
}

Other UI settings

In Gatsby-Blog-Theme, it is possible to change the design by changing the settings for other plugins, changing the highlight color/theme, or changing the UI. You can also customize the source itself. These parts should be filled in gradually.

For reference, the following is prismthe setting change for the color theme of , which supports Highlight . draculaThis is an example of setting as a preset.

// gatsby-config.js
module.exports = {
  plugins: [
    {
      resolve: `gatsby-theme-blog`,
      options: {
        prismPreset: `dracula`,
      },
    },
  ],
}

Publishing a website with Github/Git Page

You now have a basic blog configuration. Next, build a Gatsby Blog Theme and upload it to Github/GitPage to publish an actual blog post.

1) Github signup and login There are many people who sign up/activate on Github, but if you don't, it's a good idea to join this opportunity. Please log in after registering.

2) Create Github Repository Go Create Repositoryto Repository and click the button. Gatsby + GithubFor blogs, the Repository can be thought of as the following two types.

  • Generic CodeRepository: Repository to push Gatsby Source Code itself.
  • Repository for Git Page: Repository that uploads only the part created by the static site generator.

Generic Code Repository is useful for pipelines with internal CI/CD running. If you are using a Github/Jekyll combination, this is the case. Since we are using Gatsby, we cannot use this combination. However, it can be used in conjunction with Netlify. How to use it in conjunction with Netlify will be posted later.

In this post, we will create and use a Repository for Git Pages. Using Repository for Git Page is the same as using only static file storage. Again, this story is about uploading 소스파일 전체only /publicfolders , not files uploaded to Github . (We'll come back to using the gh-pages tool in the next section.)

The following is the Github Repository creation screen. Repository namewill be specified. If {userid}.github.io you specify the repository name as , it works as github pages. ex) sjwind/sjwind.github.io. https://{userid}.github.io/When you connect to in the web browser, index.htmlor index.jsis called.

In addition to the default github page, you can create a general repository and change the settings to a github page. For the sake of explanation, this part is omitted. Even if you set the general repository as a github page, it functions the same, but there is a difference in the URL when Gatsby creates a static file. For this reason, you need to adjust the --pathPrefix option. Please refer to the following article for details. https://www.gatsbyjs.com/docs/how-to/previews-deploys-hosting/how-gatsby-works-with-github-pages/

Of course, whether publicto disclose or not chooses . It acts as a web server by itself.

When linking code repository and netlify, it can be done privately.

For a detailed explanation of the Github Page, please refer to the official site. https://pages.github.com/

3) Install GitHub CLI

As described above, /publiconly the following contents should be uploaded to the github page . However, the object managed through Git is the entire Gatsby Code. It /publicwould be difficult to commit & push the following separately each time . Therefore, github provides a dedicated gitpage tool (gh-pages). Install gh-pages with the following command:

npm install gh-pages --save-dev

Next, add or modify entries in package.jsonthe script portion of deploy. gh-pages -d publicIt is /publicthe only means to push content to less than github pages.

{
  "scripts": {
       ...other options..
    "deploy": "gatsby build && gh-pages -d public"
  }
}

With this, if you now run npm run deployor gatsby deploy, it builds the code ( /publichereinafter, static site creation), and /publiccommits & pushes only the target to the github page using gh-pages .

  1. Gatsby Build and Commit

Now, the configuration for posting the blog is complete. Now, write an actual post (create a mdfile), and commit & push using git.

First time: git initialization and first commit/push

git init
git add . 
git commit -m "first commit"
git branch -M main
git remote add origin https://github.com/{userid}/{userid}.github.io.git
git push -u origin main

Commit after posting

git add . 
git commit -m "commit message ... "

distribute

Deploy runs as described above npm run deploy.

The following is the result of the repository pushed to Github (left) and the output of GitHub pages in a web browser.

Repository results pushed to Github Output from github pages

[Important] In order to exclude from uploading with git, you must .gitignoremanage the target with files.

 $ cat .gitignore
 
.env
.env.development
.env.production
.vscode

# Project dependencies
.cache
node_modules
yarn-error.log

# Build directory
.DS_Store
public/

Custom Domain Settings for Github Pages

Users who want to use a personal domain can configure Custom Domain in Github Pages. Enter the domain name you already own into the corresponding field. Of course, you need to register the CNAME record with the Domain (ex. username.github.io) provided by the Github Pages in DNS as well.

Repository > Setting menu Pages menu Custom Domain

When using Custom Domain as follows, you must also change the settings in the DNS server.

Git Page Custom Domain configuration issue

When running a blog using Github Page and Gatsby, unexpected phenomena are continuously discovered. One of them is that the Custom Domain setting is changed every time you commit. Originally, I was using the custom domain setting function provided by Github Pages as follows.

However, whenever Commit/Deploy is performed, the custom domain setting is erased. After searching the internet, it seems that this has been a topic that has been talked about for a long time. In particular, it seems to be a problem that most people who use Gatsby face.

Fortunately, a way to apply it automatically has been devised. In conclusion, you can create a CNAME file and add it.

CNAME

First of all, we looked at what changes are made to the Github Repository when custom domain is set. Change the custom domain information and click Save. After waiting for the application to be reflected for a while, I checked that the changes were reflected, and when I returned to the Repository and checked, there is a file created 23 seconds ago.

If so, you can add the CNAME file. If you open the CNAME file, the information contained in the general DNS (nslookup talbe) is included.

Not mapping DNS names and IPs. It simply contains only the domain name. Now, create a new project file and commit again.

 "deploy": "gatsby clean && gatsby build && gh-pages -b master -d public"

However, there is one problem. When deploying, ./public to github is deleted and rebuilt every time. Because of this, creating a CNAME in the /public location will not do what you want. There are two ways to keep the CNAME every time.

1. Using the Static folder

In fact, it is the simplest way. You can use it static folderby copying it to the folder that uses fixed static resources . DeployThe part that is deleted in the process /publicis , because it is automatically copied to , /staticat the time of deployment /public.

From the same point of view, later, NAVER Webmaster Tools, etc., require you to enter an html file to verify ownership. At this time, copy the file to the static folder. You can also manage ads.txt requested by Adsense in this area.

2. Copy at the time of deployment

In some cases, it is impossible to use a static folder. Therefore, the second method is to change the CNAME to /public after build when deploying. cp CNAME added below

 "deploy": "gatsby clean && gatsby build && cp CNAME ./public && gh-pages -b master -d public"
